explanation:
- struct MHD_IoVec: required to know the declaration of iov[i].iov_base and iov[i].iov_len (are they const-qualified or not). The const-qualification of iov_base in this source array is central to determining whether pointers are unnecessarily stripped of const.
- struct MHD_Response: required to see the types of response->data, response->data_iov and response->data_size (e.g. whether data/data_iov elements are declared as const-qualified pointers). Assignments like response->data = last_valid_buffer and response->data_iov = iov_copy are the spots where constness may be lost.
- MHD_iovec_: required because iov_copy is allocated as an array of MHD_iovec_. We must know the type of MHD_iovec_.iov_base (likely non-const char * or void *) and iov_len to see if the code casts away const when filling iov_copy.
- MHD_iov_size_: the typedef used for iov lengths inside MHD_iovec_. Knowing its definition is needed to understand any conversions and whether element length types force different pointer handling.
- _MHD_DROP_CONST: this macro/function is used to drop const from buffer pointers when storing into iov_copy. Its definition shows whether a const is being cast away (and how) which is directly relevant to the MISRA rule.
- MHD_IOV_ELMN_MAX_SIZE: used in the WIN64/WINSOCK splitting loop; knowing its value and role is needed to understand when and how parts of a const buffer are assigned into non-const iov entries.
- ULONG_MAX: used to compute chunking on Win64; its value and use affect when multiple non-const iov elements are created from a single (const) source buffer.
- MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS, MHD_POSIX_SOCKETS, _WIN64: these configuration macros control which code paths are compiled (e.g. whether the special Win64 splitting code and the i_cp increment behavior are in effect). To determine whether const is dropped in any build configuration you must inspect these macros.

(With these symbols available the next analyst can determine whether the implementation casts away const-qualified pointers or stores const data into non-const destinations — the exact situations that would violate the MISRA guideline that pointers should point to const-qualified types whenever possible.)
